bestBHT.bht: If a son shall ask bread of any of you that is a father, it is expected that you would not give him a stone; in the same way, if he asks for a fish, you would not offer him a serpent. This illustration provided by Jesus shows the absurdity and cruelty of a parent who would deny their child's basic needs. It is unthinkable that a loving father would intentionally harm his own child or refuse to provide for them.

Marvin Vincent: Rev., therefore, rightly, of which of you that is a father, etc.
The A. V. renders as though the pronoun were indefinite; but it is interrogative and commences the sentence.
Archibald T. Robertson: Of which of you that is a father... will ye give him a stone?"

μη shows that the answer No is expected, but the trouble is that the interrogative τινα in the first clause is in the accusative the object of αιτησε while here the same man (he) is the subject of επιδωσε.
It is a very awkward piece of Greek and yet it is intelligible.
John Gill: If a son shall ask bread of any of you that is a father,.... Our Lord illustrates and confirms what he had said before by an instance common among men..."
should he do so, he would show that his heart was as hard, or harder than the stone he gives: or if he ask a fish, will he, for a fish, give him a serpent?"
such inhuman brutish parents are not surely to be found
